title: Ron DeSantis
added: DeSantis's early tenure as Governor was affected by the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Florida|COVID-19 pandemic]]. DeSantis's response to the pandemic, in particular the December raid of [[whistleblower]] [[Rebekah Jones]]<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/florida-covid-data-scientist-raid-desantis-b1767723.html</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Florida state police raid home of Rebekah Jones, data scientist who challenged DeSantis on coronavirus statistics|url=https://news.yahoo.com/florida-state-police-raid-home-of-rebekah-jones-data-scientist-who-challenged-de-santis-on-coronavirus-statistics-010351103.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=news.yahoo.com|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Rice|first=Katie|title=Rebekah Jones, Florida's fired COVID-19 dashboard manager, has home raided by state agents with guns drawn|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/breaking-news/os-ne-rebekah-jones-florida-coronavirus-data-scientist-house-raided-20201207-ovzvszvy6fc75mn34xtbelvdl4-story.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=orlandosentinel.com}}</ref>, has been and continues to be heavily criticized; his was the only approval rating of any U.S. governor to decline after COVID-19 became widespread in the U.S.<ref>https://napequity.org/wp-content/uploads/NAPE_governor-approval-ratings_edits_5.21.20_vfinal-002.pdf</ref>

title: Ron DeSantis
deleted: DeSantis's early tenure as Governor was affected by the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Florida|COVID-19 pandemic]]. DeSantis's response to the pandemic, in particular the December raid of [[whistleblower]] [[Rebekah Jones]]<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/florida-covid-data-scientist-raid-desantis-b1767723.html</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Florida state police raid home of Rebekah Jones, data scientist who challenged DeSantis on coronavirus statistics|url=https://news.yahoo.com/florida-state-police-raid-home-of-rebekah-jones-data-scientist-who-challenged-de-santis-on-coronavirus-statistics-010351103.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=news.yahoo.com|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Rice|first=Katie|title=Rebekah Jones, Florida's fired COVID-19 dashboard manager, has home raided by state agents with guns drawn|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/breaking-news/os-ne-rebekah-jones-florida-coronavirus-data-scientist-house-raided-20201207-ovzvszvy6fc75mn34xtbelvdl4-story.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=orlandosentinel.com}}</ref>, has been and continues to be heavily criticized; his was the only approval rating of any U.S. governor to decline after COVID-19 became widespread in the U.S.<ref>https://napequity.org/wp-content/uploads/NAPE_governor-approval-ratings_edits_5.21.20_vfinal-002.pdf</ref>

title: Ron DeSantis
added: DeSantis's early tenure as Governor was affected by the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Florida|COVID-19 pandemic]]. DeSantis's response to the pandemic, in particular the December raid of [[whistleblower]] [[Rebekah Jones]]<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/florida-covid-data-scientist-raid-desantis-b1767723.html</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Florida state police raid home of Rebekah Jones, data scientist who challenged DeSantis on coronavirus statistics|url=https://news.yahoo.com/florida-state-police-raid-home-of-rebekah-jones-data-scientist-who-challenged-de-santis-on-coronavirus-statistics-010351103.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=news.yahoo.com|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Rice|first=Katie|title=Rebekah Jones, Florida's fired COVID-19 dashboard manager, has home raided by state agents with guns drawn|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/breaking-news/os-ne-rebekah-jones-florida-coronavirus-data-scientist-house-raided-20201207-ovzvszvy6fc75mn34xtbelvdl4-story.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=orlandosentinel.com}}</ref>, has been and continues to be heavily criticized; his was the only approval rating of any U.S. governor to decline after COVID-19 became widespread in the U.S.<ref>https://napequity.org/wp-content/uploads/NAPE_governor-approval-ratings_edits_5.21.20_vfinal-002.pdf</ref>
==== COVID-19 pandemic ====

DeSantis's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has been harshly criticized.<ref name="sidelined">{{Cite news |first1=Cleve R. |last1=Wootson Jr. |first2=Isaac |last2=Stanley-Becker |first3=Lori |last3=Rozsa |first4=Josh |last4=Dawsey |date=July 25, 2020 |title=Coronavirus ravaged Florida, as Ron DeSantis sidelined scientists and followed Trump |work=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/coronavirus-ravaged-florida-as-ron-desantis-sidelined-scientists-and-followed-trump/2020/07/25/0b8008da-c648-11ea-b037-f9711f89ee46_story.html}}</ref> According to the ''Sun Sentinel'', "DeSantis, who owes his job to early support from President Donald Trump, imposed an approach in line with the views of the president and his powerful base of supporters. The administration suppressed unfavorable facts, dispensed dangerous misinformation, dismissed public health professionals, and promoted the views of scientific dissenters who supported the governor’s approach to the disease."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Goodman|first=Mario Ariza, David Fleshler, Cindy Krischer|title=Secrecy and spin: How Florida's governor misled the public on the COVID-19 pandemic|url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html|access-date=2020-12-06|website=sun-sentinel.com}}</ref>

According to public health experts, politics dictated the response to COVID-19 in Florida, rather than science.<ref name="sidelined" /> DeSantis rejected the implementation of a statewide [[Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic|face mask mandate]], belatedly implemented stay-at-home orders, and let his stay-at-home order implemented in April expire.<ref name="sidelined" /> In July 2020, as Florida had become a global epicenter of the coronavirus, with nearly 5,800 deaths, DeSantis had largely sidelined health experts and scientists, with ''The Washington Post'' reporting that DeSantis primarily relied on his wife, a former television reporter, and his chief of staff, a former hospital executive.<ref name="sidelined" />

Early in the pandemic, DeSantis boasted about the low number of COVID-19 cases in Florida, and harshly criticized those who had argued that the state's lax response to the virus was insufficient.<ref name="sidelined" /><ref>{{Cite web|last=Lopez|first=German|date=2020-07-17|title=Florida now has more Covid-19 cases than any other state. Here's what went wrong.|url=https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/2020/7/17/21324398/florida-coronavirus-covid-cases-deaths-outbreak|access-date=2020-07-26|website=Vox|language=en}}</ref> Experts argued that delays in lockdown would greatly increase Florida's coronavirus numbers and leave it susceptible to becoming a new hotspot.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dixon |first1=Matt |title='Dumbest s---': DeSantis takes heat as he goes his own way on coronavirus |url=https://www.politico.com/states/florida/story/2020/03/24/dumbest-s-desantis-takes-heat-as-he-goes-his-own-way-on-coronavirus-1268818 |work=Politico |access-date=12 April 2020 |language=en |date=24 March 2020}}</ref>

On March 8, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] privately briefed DeSantis that Florida was already experiencing community spread of COVID-19, however  the next day, DeSantis publicly denied that Florida was experiencing community spread of COVID-19.<ref name="Ariza">{{cite news |last1=Ariza |first1=Mario |last2=Fleshler |first2=David |last3=Goodman |first3=Cindy |title=Secrecy and spin: How Florida's governor misled the public on the COVID-19 pandemic |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html |access-date=December 4, 2020 |work=[[South Florida Sun Sentinel]] |archive-date=December 3, 2020| date=December 3, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201203214624/https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html}}</ref> On March 10, federal official Dr. [[Anthony Fauci]] publicly confirmed that Florida had community spread, while DeSantis only confirmed Florida's community spread on March 14.<ref name="Ariza"/>

By the end of March 2020, Florida had 6,741 confirmed cases of COVID-19. DeSantis declared that he would not issue a statewide [[Stay-at-home order|stay-at-home]] order because the Trump administration had not recommended that he do so.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/04/01/coronavirus-florida-desantis/|title=Florida covid-19 cases surge to nearly 7,000 as Ron DeSantis resists statewide restrictions|date=April 1, 2020|author=Barbash, Fred|access-date=April 1, 2020|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> Then, on April 1, DeSantis ordered that all Floridians stay home for 30 days with exceptions for essential services and activities.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rohrer |first1=Gray |last2=Lemongello |first2=Steven |date=April 1, 2020 |title=DeSantis announces statewide shutdown order for Florida through April |url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/coronavirus/os-ne-coronavirus-desantis-wednesday-20200401-yc2ttrxuw5hx7ci3zn2id3ynlq-story.html |access-date=April 1, 2020 |newspaper=Orlando Sentinel}}</ref> DeSantis received criticism for falsely stating on April 9 that that no fatalities under 25 had been caused in the United States by COVID-19. DeSantis acknowledged this error after critics pointed it out, and clarified that there have been no deaths from the virus in people under 25 in Florida.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Johnson |first1=Martin |title=Florida Gov. DeSantis mulls reopening schools: Coronavirus 'doesn't seem to threaten' kids |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/492152-florida-gov-desantis-says-coronavirus-doesnt-seem-to-threaten-kids-mulls |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |access-date=12 April 2020 |language=en |date=10 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Putterman |first1=Samantha |title=Florida governor falsely claims novel coronavirus hasn't killed anyone under 25 in the US |url=https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/apr/10/ron-desantis/florida-governor-falsely-claims-novel-coronavirus-/ |website=PolitiFact |access-date=July 15, 2020 |date=April 10, 2020}}</ref> In early June, DeSantis partially lifted his stay-at-home order, lifting restrictions on bars and cinemas; on the same day that he lifted the restrictions, Florida recorded the largest case surge in six weeks.<ref name="sidelined" />

DeSantis sought to have the [[2020 Republican National Convention]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]]. In conversations with President Trump in May, DeSantis said he would not require the use of face masks.<ref name="sidelined" /> However, by July, as Florida became a global epicenter of the virus, Trump called off the event in Jacksonville.<ref name="sidelined" />

In June 2020, DeSantis came under increased scrutiny after a surge in [[COVID-19]] cases, which started approximately four weeks after Florida initiated the reopening process. DeSantis said that the bulk of new cases were present in "younger cohorts," and argued that an increase in testing, particularly of asymptomatic individuals, and more efficient identification of outbreaks in areas such as [[prisons]] and in Florida's [[agriculture]] sector were responsible for the majority of the increases. He emphasized that the strain on the hospital system and medical supplies such as ventilators had decreased since the prior "peak" in case numbers, and that Florida was ready to handle any additional influx in hospital patients; adding that the state had "twice as many" open hospital beds than on March 1. Amid calls on DeSantis to re-instate restrictions on business activity in late June to halt the spread of the virus, DeSantis said Florida is "not going back" on reopening the economy, arguing that "people going to a business is not what's driving" the surge in cases.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Rummler |first=Orion |title=Florida is "not going back" on reopening, governor says |url=https://www.axios.com/florida-coronavirus-desantis-3fe9b6c4-532b-4b2f-bf20-391e586abd2d.html |access-date=2020-06-30 |work=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] |language=en |date=June 30, 2020}}</ref>

Starting June 2020, Florida experienced a resurgence of COVID-19 cases, nearly tripling the percent positive rate of tests for COVID-19 in a span of three weeks. On June 28, 2020, DeSantis said Florida was in "good shape" in its fight against COVID-19,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Burke |first1=Peter |title=DeSantis says Florida in 'good shape' in fight against coronavirus |url=https://www.wptv.com/news/state/desantis-says-florida-in-good-shape-in-fight-against-coronavirus |access-date=July 6, 2020 |work=[[WPTV]] |date=June 28, 2020 |language=en}}</ref> despite Florida, the third largest state, having the sixth most confirmed [[COVID-19]] cases in the nation {{As of|2020|6|28|alt=as of that date}}.<ref>{{cite web |title=United States Coronavirus: 2,596,364 Cases and 128,152 Deaths |url=https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ |website=Worldometer |access-date=July 6, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200628000052/https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ |archive-date=June 28, 2020 |date=June 28, 2020 |url-status=unfit}}</ref>

For a period in the summer, Florida, the third largest state in the United States, had the third most confirmed [[COVID-19]] cases and the most active cases in the nation {{As of|2020|7|19|df=US|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite web |title=United States Coronavirus: 3,893,964 Cases and 143,263 Deaths |url=https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ |website=Worldometer |access-date=July 25, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200719235938/https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ |archive-date=July 19, 2020 |date=July 19, 2020 |url-status=unfit}}</ref><ref name="sidelined" /> In September 2020, DeSantis lifted all restrictions on capacity in bars and restaurants, despite persistent cases.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Solomon |first1=Josh |last2=Ceballos |first2=Ana |title=DeSantis lifts statewide restrictions on bars and restaurants as Florida moves to phase 3 |url=https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2020/09/25/desantis-bars-and-restaurants-can-go-to-full-capacity-as-florida-moves-to-phase-3/ |access-date=October 14, 2020 |work=Tampa Bay Times |date=September 25, 2020 |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite news |title=Florida lifts all coronavirus restaurant restrictions despite persistent cases |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/florida-governor-ron-desantis-lifts-coronavirus-restaurant-restrictions-statewide/ |access-date=October 14, 2020 |work=[[CBS News]] |language=en-US |date=September 25, 2020}}</ref> He also banned cities and counties collecting fines from face mask mandates.<ref name=":0" /> He also urged public health officials in Florida cities to focus less on universal COVID-19 testing.<ref>{{cite news |first1=John |last1=Avlon |first2=Michael |last2=Warren |first3=Brandon |last3=Miller |title=Atlas push to 'slow the testing down' tracks with dramatic decline in one key state |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/29/politics/atlas-desantis-testing-covid-florida/index.html |access-date=2020-10-29 |work=CNN |date=October 29, 2020}}</ref>

With regard to tackling the pandemic, the DeSantis administration largely ignored Florida's own scientists in the state's [[Emerging Pathogens Institute]], reported the ''[[South Florida Sun Sentinel]]''.<ref name="Ariza"/> Instead, in August and September 2020, DeSantis invited into Florida other scientists who endorsed less-restrictive COVID-19 policies that DeSantis agreed with, so that they could conduct press conferences together with DeSantis.<ref name="Ariza"/> This included radiologist [[Scott Atlas]], who had been widely condemned by other scientists for his views on how to handle the crisis.<ref name="Ariza"/>

In November 2020, it was revealed that DeSantis had hired a sports blogger known for pushing COVID-19 disinformation to the state's Office of Policy and Budget in a data analyst position.<ref>{{Cite news |first1=Nicholas |last1=Nehamas |first2=Ben |last2=Conarck |first3=Kirby |last3=Wilson |date=November 10, 2020 |title=DeSantis' latest hire for data team: Uber-driving, COVID-conspiracy sports blogger |work=Miami Herald |url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/coronavirus/article247081417.html |access-date=November 11, 2020}}</ref>

During Trump's re-election campaign, DeSantis worked to help him win Florida. DeSantis attended Trump's rallies where he high-fived attendees while not wearing a mask, contrary to public health guidance.<ref name=":1" />

A journalistic investigation was undertaken by the ''[[Sun Sentinel]]'' in December 2020.<ref>{{Cite news |first1=Mario |last1=Ariza |first2=David |last2=Fleshler |first3=Cindy Krischer|last3=Goodman |date=December 2, 2020 |title= How Florida Gov. DeSantis misled the public on COVID crisis |work=Sun Sentinel |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html}}</ref> The article asserted that DeSantis misled the general public at large about the severity of the pandemic in such a way that aligned with the rhetoric of President [[Donald Trump|Trump]] on the matter. It stated that DeSantis suppressed facts, dispended dangerous misinformation, dismissed public health professionals, and promoted the views of scientific dissenters. Five days after the report from the ''Sun Sentinel'', news outlets reported that law enforcement in the state raided the home of [[Rebekah Jones]] – a former employee for the [[Florida Department of Health]] who was fired back in May 2020 for creating an informative dashboard about the virus and the pandemic in the state online.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Bill |last=Chappell |date=December 8, 2020 |work=NPR|title=Florida Agents Raid Home Of Rebekah Jones, Former State Data Scientist |url=https://www.npr.org/2020/12/08/944200394/florida-agents-raid-home-of-rebekah-jones-former-state-data-scientist}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |first1=Casey |last1=Tolan |first2=Curt |last2=Devine| date=December 8, 2020|title=Florida police raid home of former state Covid-19 data scientist |work=CNN |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/07/us/florida-search-warrant-raid-rebekah-jones-invs/index.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |first=Alexander | last=Nazaryan | date=December 7, 2020|title=Florida state police raid home of Rebekah Jones, data scientist who challenged DeSantis on coronavirus statistics | work=Yahoo News | url=https://news.yahoo.com/florida-state-police-raid-home-of-rebekah-jones-data-scientist-who-challenged-de-santis-on-coronavirus-statistics-010351103.html}}</ref> It was alleged that DeSantis was trying to intimidate her.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Matt |last=Cannon |date=December 8, 2020 |work=Newsweek |url=https://www.newsweek.com/rebekah-jones-says-florida-gov-desantis-trying-intimidate-scientists-raiding-her-home-1553064|title=Rebekah Jones Says Florida Gov. DeSantis Trying to 'Intimidate Scientists' By Raiding Her Home}}</ref> The raid led to the resignation of an attorney who was appointed by the governor named Ron Filipkowski.<ref>{{Cite news |first= Reimann |last= Nicolas |date=December 8, 2020 |work=Forbes|title=DeSantis Aide Quits Over Florida Covid Policy And Police Raid Of Data Scientist |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nicholasreimann/2020/12/08/desantis-aide-quits-over-florida-covid-policy-and-police-raid-of-data-scientist/?sh=6bf6bc28318d}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |first=Mary Ellen |last=Klas |date=December 8, 2020|title=GOP lawyer resigns over treatment of Florida data analyst |work=Tampa Bay Times |url=https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2020/12/08/gop-lawyer-resigns-over-treatment-of-florida-data-analyst/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |first=Zac |last=Anderson |date=December 8, 2020 |work=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|title= Sarasota attorney resigns state job to protest Rebekah Jones raid|url=https://www.heraldtribune.com/story/news/politics/2020/12/08/florida-republican-attorney-resigns-rebekah-jones-raid-gov-desantis-ron-filipkowski-sarasota/6493391002/}}</ref>

title: Ron DeSantis
added: DeSantis's early tenure as Governor was affected by the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Florida|COVID-19 pandemic]]. DeSantis's response to the pandemic, in particular the December raid of [[whistleblower]] [[Rebekah Jones]]<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/florida-covid-data-scientist-raid-desantis-b1767723.html</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Florida state police raid home of Rebekah Jones, data scientist who challenged DeSantis on coronavirus statistics|url=https://news.yahoo.com/florida-state-police-raid-home-of-rebekah-jones-data-scientist-who-challenged-de-santis-on-coronavirus-statistics-010351103.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=news.yahoo.com|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Rice|first=Katie|title=Rebekah Jones, Florida's fired COVID-19 dashboard manager, has home raided by state agents with guns drawn|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/breaking-news/os-ne-rebekah-jones-florida-coronavirus-data-scientist-house-raided-20201207-ovzvszvy6fc75mn34xtbelvdl4-story.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=orlandosentinel.com}}</ref>, has been and continues to be heavily criticized; his was the only approval rating of any U.S. governor to decline after COVID-19 became widespread in the U.S.<ref>https://napequity.org/wp-content/uploads/NAPE_governor-approval-ratings_edits_5.21.20_vfinal-002.pdf</ref>
==== COVID-19 pandemic ====

DeSantis's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has been harshly criticized.<ref name="sidelined">{{Cite news |first1=Cleve R. |last1=Wootson Jr. |first2=Isaac |last2=Stanley-Becker |first3=Lori |last3=Rozsa |first4=Josh |last4=Dawsey |date=July 25, 2020 |title=Coronavirus ravaged Florida, as Ron DeSantis sidelined scientists and followed Trump |work=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/coronavirus-ravaged-florida-as-ron-desantis-sidelined-scientists-and-followed-trump/2020/07/25/0b8008da-c648-11ea-b037-f9711f89ee46_story.html}}</ref> According to the ''Sun Sentinel'', "DeSantis, who owes his job to early support from President Donald Trump, imposed an approach in line with the views of the president and his powerful base of supporters. The administration suppressed unfavorable facts, dispensed dangerous misinformation, dismissed public health professionals, and promoted the views of scientific dissenters who supported the governor’s approach to the disease."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Goodman|first=Mario Ariza, David Fleshler, Cindy Krischer|title=Secrecy and spin: How Florida's governor misled the public on the COVID-19 pandemic|url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html|access-date=2020-12-06|website=sun-sentinel.com}}</ref>

According to public health experts, politics dictated the response to COVID-19 in Florida, rather than science.<ref name="sidelined" /> DeSantis rejected the implementation of a statewide [[Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic|face mask mandate]], belatedly implemented stay-at-home orders, and let his stay-at-home order implemented in April expire.<ref name="sidelined" /> In July 2020, as Florida had become a global epicenter of the coronavirus, with nearly 5,800 deaths, DeSantis had largely sidelined health experts and scientists, with ''The Washington Post'' reporting that DeSantis primarily relied on his wife, a former television reporter, and his chief of staff, a former hospital executive.<ref name="sidelined" />

Early in the pandemic, DeSantis boasted about the low number of COVID-19 cases in Florida, and harshly criticized those who had argued that the state's lax response to the virus was insufficient.<ref name="sidelined" /><ref>{{Cite web|last=Lopez|first=German|date=2020-07-17|title=Florida now has more Covid-19 cases than any other state. Here's what went wrong.|url=https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/2020/7/17/21324398/florida-coronavirus-covid-cases-deaths-outbreak|access-date=2020-07-26|website=Vox|language=en}}</ref> Experts argued that delays in lockdown would greatly increase Florida's coronavirus numbers and leave it susceptible to becoming a new hotspot.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dixon |first1=Matt |title='Dumbest s---': DeSantis takes heat as he goes his own way on coronavirus |url=https://www.politico.com/states/florida/story/2020/03/24/dumbest-s-desantis-takes-heat-as-he-goes-his-own-way-on-coronavirus-1268818 |work=Politico |access-date=12 April 2020 |language=en |date=24 March 2020}}</ref>

On March 8, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] privately briefed DeSantis that Florida was already experiencing community spread of COVID-19, however  the next day, DeSantis publicly denied that Florida was experiencing community spread of COVID-19.<ref name="Ariza">{{cite news |last1=Ariza |first1=Mario |last2=Fleshler |first2=David |last3=Goodman |first3=Cindy |title=Secrecy and spin: How Florida's governor misled the public on the COVID-19 pandemic |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html |access-date=December 4, 2020 |work=[[South Florida Sun Sentinel]] |archive-date=December 3, 2020| date=December 3, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201203214624/https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html}}</ref> On March 10, federal official Dr. [[Anthony Fauci]] publicly confirmed that Florida had community spread, while DeSantis only confirmed Florida's community spread on March 14.<ref name="Ariza"/>

By the end of March 2020, Florida had 6,741 confirmed cases of COVID-19. DeSantis declared that he would not issue a statewide [[Stay-at-home order|stay-at-home]] order because the Trump administration had not recommended that he do so.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/04/01/coronavirus-florida-desantis/|title=Florida covid-19 cases surge to nearly 7,000 as Ron DeSantis resists statewide restrictions|date=April 1, 2020|author=Barbash, Fred|access-date=April 1, 2020|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> Then, on April 1, DeSantis ordered that all Floridians stay home for 30 days with exceptions for essential services and activities.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rohrer |first1=Gray |last2=Lemongello |first2=Steven |date=April 1, 2020 |title=DeSantis announces statewide shutdown order for Florida through April |url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/coronavirus/os-ne-coronavirus-desantis-wednesday-20200401-yc2ttrxuw5hx7ci3zn2id3ynlq-story.html |access-date=April 1, 2020 |newspaper=Orlando Sentinel}}</ref> DeSantis received criticism for falsely stating on April 9 that that no fatalities under 25 had been caused in the United States by COVID-19. DeSantis acknowledged this error after critics pointed it out, and clarified that there have been no deaths from the virus in people under 25 in Florida.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Johnson |first1=Martin |title=Florida Gov. DeSantis mulls reopening schools: Coronavirus 'doesn't seem to threaten' kids |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/492152-florida-gov-desantis-says-coronavirus-doesnt-seem-to-threaten-kids-mulls |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |access-date=12 April 2020 |language=en |date=10 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Putterman |first1=Samantha |title=Florida governor falsely claims novel coronavirus hasn't killed anyone under 25 in the US |url=https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/apr/10/ron-desantis/florida-governor-falsely-claims-novel-coronavirus-/ |website=PolitiFact |access-date=July 15, 2020 |date=April 10, 2020}}</ref> In early June, DeSantis partially lifted his stay-at-home order, lifting restrictions on bars and cinemas; on the same day that he lifted the restrictions, Florida recorded the largest case surge in six weeks.<ref name="sidelined" />

DeSantis sought to have the [[2020 Republican National Convention]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]]. In conversations with President Trump in May, DeSantis said he would not require the use of face masks.<ref name="sidelined" /> However, by July, as Florida became a global epicenter of the virus, Trump called off the event in Jacksonville.<ref name="sidelined" />

In June 2020, DeSantis came under increased scrutiny after a surge in [[COVID-19]] cases, which started approximately four weeks after Florida initiated the reopening process. DeSantis said that the bulk of new cases were present in "younger cohorts," and argued that an increase in testing, particularly of asymptomatic individuals, and more efficient identification of outbreaks in areas such as [[prisons]] and in Florida's [[agriculture]] sector were responsible for the majority of the increases. He emphasized that the strain on the hospital system and medical supplies such as ventilators had decreased since the prior "peak" in case numbers, and that Florida was ready to handle any additional influx in hospital patients; adding that the state had "twice as many" open hospital beds than on March 1. Amid calls on DeSantis to re-instate restrictions on business activity in late June to halt the spread of the virus, DeSantis said Florida is "not going back" on reopening the economy, arguing that "people going to a business is not what's driving" the surge in cases.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Rummler |first=Orion |title=Florida is "not going back" on reopening, governor says |url=https://www.axios.com/florida-coronavirus-desantis-3fe9b6c4-532b-4b2f-bf20-391e586abd2d.html |access-date=2020-06-30 |work=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] |language=en |date=June 30, 2020}}</ref>

Starting June 2020, Florida experienced a resurgence of COVID-19 cases, nearly tripling the percent positive rate of tests for COVID-19 in a span of three weeks. On June 28, 2020, DeSantis said Florida was in "good shape" in its fight against COVID-19,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Burke |first1=Peter |title=DeSantis says Florida in 'good shape' in fight against coronavirus |url=https://www.wptv.com/news/state/desantis-says-florida-in-good-shape-in-fight-against-coronavirus |access-date=July 6, 2020 |work=[[WPTV]] |date=June 28, 2020 |language=en}}</ref> despite Florida, the third largest state, having the sixth most confirmed [[COVID-19]] cases in the nation {{As of|2020|6|28|alt=as of that date}}.<ref>{{cite web |title=United States Coronavirus: 2,596,364 Cases and 128,152 Deaths |url=https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ |website=Worldometer |access-date=July 6, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200628000052/https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ |archive-date=June 28, 2020 |date=June 28, 2020 |url-status=unfit}}</ref>

For a period in the summer, Florida, the third largest state in the United States, had the third most confirmed [[COVID-19]] cases and the most active cases in the nation {{As of|2020|7|19|df=US|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite web |title=United States Coronavirus: 3,893,964 Cases and 143,263 Deaths |url=https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ |website=Worldometer |access-date=July 25, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200719235938/https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ |archive-date=July 19, 2020 |date=July 19, 2020 |url-status=unfit}}</ref><ref name="sidelined" /> In September 2020, DeSantis lifted all restrictions on capacity in bars and restaurants, despite persistent cases.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Solomon |first1=Josh |last2=Ceballos |first2=Ana |title=DeSantis lifts statewide restrictions on bars and restaurants as Florida moves to phase 3 |url=https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2020/09/25/desantis-bars-and-restaurants-can-go-to-full-capacity-as-florida-moves-to-phase-3/ |access-date=October 14, 2020 |work=Tampa Bay Times |date=September 25, 2020 |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite news |title=Florida lifts all coronavirus restaurant restrictions despite persistent cases |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/florida-governor-ron-desantis-lifts-coronavirus-restaurant-restrictions-statewide/ |access-date=October 14, 2020 |work=[[CBS News]] |language=en-US |date=September 25, 2020}}</ref> He also banned cities and counties collecting fines from face mask mandates.<ref name=":0" /> He also urged public health officials in Florida cities to focus less on universal COVID-19 testing.<ref>{{cite news |first1=John |last1=Avlon |first2=Michael |last2=Warren |first3=Brandon |last3=Miller |title=Atlas push to 'slow the testing down' tracks with dramatic decline in one key state |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/29/politics/atlas-desantis-testing-covid-florida/index.html |access-date=2020-10-29 |work=CNN |date=October 29, 2020}}</ref>

With regard to tackling the pandemic, the DeSantis administration largely ignored Florida's own scientists in the state's [[Emerging Pathogens Institute]], reported the ''[[South Florida Sun Sentinel]]''.<ref name="Ariza"/> Instead, in August and September 2020, DeSantis invited into Florida other scientists who endorsed less-restrictive COVID-19 policies that DeSantis agreed with, so that they could conduct press conferences together with DeSantis.<ref name="Ariza"/> This included radiologist [[Scott Atlas]], who had been widely condemned by other scientists for his views on how to handle the crisis.<ref name="Ariza"/>

In November 2020, it was revealed that DeSantis had hired a sports blogger known for pushing COVID-19 disinformation to the state's Office of Policy and Budget in a data analyst position.<ref>{{Cite news |first1=Nicholas |last1=Nehamas |first2=Ben |last2=Conarck |first3=Kirby |last3=Wilson |date=November 10, 2020 |title=DeSantis' latest hire for data team: Uber-driving, COVID-conspiracy sports blogger |work=Miami Herald |url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/coronavirus/article247081417.html |access-date=November 11, 2020}}</ref>

During Trump's re-election campaign, DeSantis worked to help him win Florida. DeSantis attended Trump's rallies where he high-fived attendees while not wearing a mask, contrary to public health guidance.<ref name=":1" />

A journalistic investigation was undertaken by the ''[[Sun Sentinel]]'' in December 2020.<ref>{{Cite news |first1=Mario |last1=Ariza |first2=David |last2=Fleshler |first3=Cindy Krischer|last3=Goodman |date=December 2, 2020 |title= How Florida Gov. DeSantis misled the public on COVID crisis |work=Sun Sentinel |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html}}</ref> The article asserted that DeSantis misled the general public at large about the severity of the pandemic in such a way that aligned with the rhetoric of President [[Donald Trump|Trump]] on the matter. It stated that DeSantis suppressed facts, dispended dangerous misinformation, dismissed public health professionals, and promoted the views of scientific dissenters. Five days after the report from the ''Sun Sentinel'', news outlets reported that law enforcement in the state raided the home of [[Rebekah Jones]] – a former employee for the [[Florida Department of Health]] who was fired back in May 2020 for creating an informative dashboard about the virus and the pandemic in the state online.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Bill |last=Chappell |date=December 8, 2020 |work=NPR|title=Florida Agents Raid Home Of Rebekah Jones, Former State Data Scientist |url=https://www.npr.org/2020/12/08/944200394/florida-agents-raid-home-of-rebekah-jones-former-state-data-scientist}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |first1=Casey |last1=Tolan |first2=Curt |last2=Devine| date=December 8, 2020|title=Florida police raid home of former state Covid-19 data scientist |work=CNN |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/07/us/florida-search-warrant-raid-rebekah-jones-invs/index.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |first=Alexander | last=Nazaryan | date=December 7, 2020|title=Florida state police raid home of Rebekah Jones, data scientist who challenged DeSantis on coronavirus statistics | work=Yahoo News | url=https://news.yahoo.com/florida-state-police-raid-home-of-rebekah-jones-data-scientist-who-challenged-de-santis-on-coronavirus-statistics-010351103.html}}</ref> It was alleged that DeSantis was trying to intimidate her.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Matt |last=Cannon |date=December 8, 2020 |work=Newsweek |url=https://www.newsweek.com/rebekah-jones-says-florida-gov-desantis-trying-intimidate-scientists-raiding-her-home-1553064|title=Rebekah Jones Says Florida Gov. DeSantis Trying to 'Intimidate Scientists' By Raiding Her Home}}</ref> The raid led to the resignation of an attorney who was appointed by the governor named Ron Filipkowski.<ref>{{Cite news |first= Reimann |last= Nicolas |date=December 8, 2020 |work=Forbes|title=DeSantis Aide Quits Over Florida Covid Policy And Police Raid Of Data Scientist |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nicholasreimann/2020/12/08/desantis-aide-quits-over-florida-covid-policy-and-police-raid-of-data-scientist/?sh=6bf6bc28318d}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |first=Mary Ellen |last=Klas |date=December 8, 2020|title=GOP lawyer resigns over treatment of Florida data analyst |work=Tampa Bay Times |url=https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2020/12/08/gop-lawyer-resigns-over-treatment-of-florida-data-analyst/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |first=Zac |last=Anderson |date=December 8, 2020 |work=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|title= Sarasota attorney resigns state job to protest Rebekah Jones raid|url=https://www.heraldtribune.com/story/news/politics/2020/12/08/florida-republican-attorney-resigns-rebekah-jones-raid-gov-desantis-ron-filipkowski-sarasota/6493391002/}}</ref>

title: Ron DeSantis
added: DeSantis's early tenure as Governor was affected by the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Florida|COVID-19 pandemic]]. DeSantis's response to the pandemic, in particular the December raid of [[whistleblower]] [[Rebekah Jones]],<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/florida-covid-data-scientist-raid-desantis-b1767723.html</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Florida state police raid home of Rebekah Jones, data scientist who challenged DeSantis on coronavirus statistics|url=https://news.yahoo.com/florida-state-police-raid-home-of-rebekah-jones-data-scientist-who-challenged-de-santis-on-coronavirus-statistics-010351103.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=news.yahoo.com|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Rice|first=Katie|title=Rebekah Jones, Florida's fired COVID-19 dashboard manager, has home raided by state agents with guns drawn|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/breaking-news/os-ne-rebekah-jones-florida-coronavirus-data-scientist-house-raided-20201207-ovzvszvy6fc75mn34xtbelvdl4-story.html|access-date=2020-12-08|website=orlandosentinel.com}}</ref> has been and continues to be heavily criticized; his was the only approval rating of any U.S. governor to decline after COVID-19 became widespread in the U.S.<ref>https://napequity.org/wp-content/uploads/NAPE_governor-approval-ratings_edits_5.21.20_vfinal-002.pdf</ref>

title: Ron DeSantis
deleted: During Trump's re-election campaign, DeSantis worked to help him win Florida. DeSantis attended Trump's rallies where he high-fived attendees while not wearing a mask, contrary to public health guidance.<ref name=":1" />

title: Ron DeSantis
deleted: On March 8, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] privately briefed DeSantis that Florida was already experiencing community spread of COVID-19, however  the next day, DeSantis publicly denied that Florida was experiencing community spread of COVID-19.<ref name="Ariza">{{cite news |last1=Ariza |first1=Mario |last2=Fleshler |first2=David |last3=Goodman |first3=Cindy |title=Secrecy and spin: How Florida's governor misled the public on the COVID-19 pandemic |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html |access-date=December 4, 2020 |work=[[South Florida Sun Sentinel]] |archive-date=December 3, 2020| date=December 3, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201203214624/https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-florida-desantis-spin-ss-prem-20201203-tyjmgkos6bd7vo7vnripqliany-htmlstory.html}}</ref> On March 10, federal official Dr. [[Anthony Fauci]] publicly confirmed that Florida had community spread, while DeSantis only confirmed Florida's community spread on March 14.<ref name="Ariza"/>
